response.answer_text: Let's first understand, what's wisdom? The ability to make sensible decisions and judgements because of your knowledge or experience. Definition source- Google dictionary. Wisdom is the gap between theory and practical. It's about extracting useful information from knowledge and experiences and applying it in decision-making. For example- Applying brakes to stop a car is theory, and knowing this theory is knowledge. Applying brakes fast to stop a car instantly is also knowledge. Once, I applied the brakes of my vehicle with high pressure. However, it stopped only after a few seconds. This is an experience, which altered my knowledge a little. Some days back I was driving a car on the highway, suddenly the car ahead stopped as it missed a turn. I immediately applied the brakes to avoid an accident, but not with high pressure. Thus my vehicle stopped only after dragging for a few metres, inches away from the car. My father, who was sitting beside me asked me the reason of applying brakes slowly. I explained him how a truck was speeding behind us and if I would have pressed the brakes hard, the truck driver wouldn't be able to stop the heavy vehicle on time despite applying the brakes, and we could have been a part of a major accident. By applying brakes a little slow, I made a balance between the vehicle ahead and the truck at the back and saved our car from an accident from any of the side. The way I used my knowledge, observation and experience to take the best decision in the critical situation is wisdom. Question- Can wisdom be taught? Yes, wisdom can be taught by experienced people, like I shared this example with you. Next time you drive a vehicle, you would be careful about this aspect. However, the best way to acquire wisdom is by analysing other people's actions and experiences, and by learning from our failures and experiences. Wisdom can't be acquired only by reading books. Be observant and a good listener to be wise.

Yes, and no. Allow me to explain, but first, let's look at what wisdom means.  ​ Wisdom is inherently good judgement. You may have knowledge, and you may acquire experience, but if you fail to make good judgement, it's pointless to have the other two. While knowledge can be taught, and you may also learn vicariously through the experiences of others, but the most important aspect, i.e. the ability to make good judgement can not be taught. For example, a person who has years of experience, and has acquired vast knowledge may in a fit of anger, or when overcome by lust, fail to make sound judgement.  We all have weaknesses like envy, lust, anger, greed, and pride that can lay waste to all our knowledge and experience. The one who is able to keep these vices in check is the wise master.  However, how you may keep these vices in check can not be taught. It's what you teach yourself.

Vicarious experiences can be extremely valuable. In 8th grade, I was taught about the wisdom of using condoms from people who had experienced first hand just how bad things could be if condoms weren't used. That stuck with me, fortunately. In fact wisdom should be taught more in schools. There are so many important life lessons to learn. Wisdom is arguably more important - as it confers happiness later if life, much more so than the ability to memorize data for tests.
